newsitem.title: JAPAN: Tokyo gold futures end mixed, others mostly lower.
newsitem.headline: Tokyo gold futures end mixed, others mostly lower.

text.p: Yen-based Tokyo gold futures ended narrowly mixed on Tuesday in directionless trade, while other precious metal futures were mostly lower reflecting losses in New York overnight, traders said.
Gold futures ranged from four yen per gram lower to three yen firmer. Benchmark February was flat at 1,382 yen.
Platinum futures ranged from eight yen to 20 yen per gram lower, with benchmark February down 14 yen at 1,455 yen.
Gold prices slipped from their early highs as private investors sold gold and took fresh long positions in platinum due to the narrowing gold/platinum spread, traders said.
In the bullion market, spot gold was quoted at $350.30/351.00 per ounce at 0730 GMT, down from $350.70/351.20 in New York on Monday.
"Japanese trade houses bought relatively cheaper Tokyo gold futures and sold spot gold in arbitrage dealings, which dented spot prices," one trader said.
Activity in gold futures was thin as the yen's rebound against the dollar late in the day made private investors cautious about taking large fresh positions, traders said.
Platinum futures opened lower, but fresh buying partly cut the early losses, traders said.
Activity in palladium futures was sluggish amid a dearth of fresh incentives.

Private investors still held massive short positions in TOCOM palladium futures, while foreign funds held large long positions overseas, traders said. "Although market players are waiting for fresh news from Russia, the palladium price outlook partly hinges on which side (TOCOM or the overseas funds) will win," one trader said.
Benchmark February palladium ended down five yen per gram at 565 yen. Benchmark February silver finished down 2.2 yen per 10 grams at 202.0 yen.
